user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Console_CopyOut:
```c
static int32 OS_Console_CopyOut(OS_console_internal_record_t *console, const char *Str, size_t *NextWritePos)
{
    const char *pmsg;
    size_t      WriteOffset;
    int32       return_code;

    return_code = OS_ERROR;
    pmsg        = Str;
    WriteOffset = *NextWritePos;
    while (true)
    {
        if (*pmsg == 0)
        {
            /* String is complete */
            *NextWritePos = WriteOffset;
            return_code   = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }
        console->BufBase[WriteOffset] = *pmsg;
        WriteOffset                   = WriteOffset + 1;
        if (WriteOffset >= console->BufSize)
        {
            WriteOffset = 0;
        }

        if (WriteOffset == console->ReadPos)
        {
            /* out of space */
            return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
            break;
        }

        ++pmsg;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_Console_CopyOut:
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_QUEUE_FULL (-9)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ERROR;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The assignment 'return_code = OS_ERROR;' is executed unconditionally at the start of the function before any possible returns or jumps, so it is reachable on every invocation. There is no unreachable code related to this fragment, therefore Rule 2.1 is not violated.
